I have therefore cited these passages, not only that it may be shown that there were women-Pharisees, and so that the name is not taken from interpretz'ny or eoepoundiny, but that it may be observed also what kind of women, for the most part, embrace Pharisaisnu namely‚ widows and maids, under the veil of sanctity and devotion, hiding· and practising all manner of wickedness. And so much we gain of the history of the Pharisaes, while we are tracing the etymology of the word.

II. That the Pharisees therefore were so called from the word ΨἾΞ, signifying separation, is more commonly asserted, and more truly; and the thing itseff, as well as the word, speaks it. So that by a word more known to us, you might rightly call the phariseos, Separatists ; but in what sense, has need of more narrow inquiry.
